etymology.description: 亻(人) (rén, "person") + 巾(巾) (jīn, "cloth") as phonetic = person with cloth or headdress -> sovereign or emperor
etymology.interpretation: The character 帝(帝) (dì, "emperor") combines 人(人) (rén, "person"), indicating a person, with 巾(巾) (jīn, "cloth"), representing the garments of high status. This suggests a person adorned, symbolizing sovereignty or divine status.

examples.chinese: 天帝庇佑万物(天帝庇佑萬物)。
examples.english: The Heavenly Emperor protects all beings.

examples.chinese: 他被世人尊为帝(他被世人尊為帝)，享有无上荣耀(享有無上榮耀)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bèi shìrén zūn wéi dì, xiǎng yǒu wú shàng róngyào.
examples.english: He is revered as an emperor by the people, enjoying supreme glory.

examples.chinese: 秦始皇帝统一六国(秦始皇帝統一六國)。
examples.english: The First Emperor of Qin unified the Six States.
